author: @arenashawn772
text: I love this video ( in the same spirit of many other of your machine learning algorithm videos) because after watching it, I actually managed to code a simple classification tree on my own to just solidify the things I learned here, and after watching this video, all the parameters in scikit-learn DecisionTreeClassifier are making sense to me. Most of the ML videos and many of the classes out there only talk about very generalized, high-level ideas of these models. You don‚Äôt. You always do such a great job giving clear yet detailed explanation of the nitty gritty of these models. Between the ISLP/ISLR books and your videos I am able to gain basic understanding beyond just making api calls of caret in R or sklearn in python. It really made me feel like I am learning, instead of just typing formulas on the keyboard. Could never thank you enough ‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§

author: @user-nk8ry3xs5u
text: Hi Josh, Many many thanks for you invaluable videos which make complex concepts / models easier to understand! Not sure if you ended up finding where Gini comes from, Wikipedia has is as being named after and Italian mathematician. "Gini impurity Gini impurity, Gini's diversity index,[23] or Gini-Simpson Index in biodiversity research, is named after Italian mathematician Corrado Gini and used by the CART (classification and regression tree) algorithm for classification trees. " (source Wikipedia)

author: @panzhang9751
text: One question , In regression tree, we use sum-of-square as loss function for training the model, so we can obtain predicted rule as mean of sample labels in the leaf node. However, why do we use Gini index in classification tree? It's definitely not a loss function! Loss function should be a measure between predicted labels and true labels, but Gini index just involve predicted label. If no loss function, how do we train the model? What's more, we cannot derive a predicted rule as in regression problem as mean of samples' label, so why do we predict a new sample as majority voting?Ôºàmost frequent labels in one leaf nodeÔºâ. Why is it reasonable?

author: @panzhang9751
text: Bug: you just calculate the weighted Gini index for leaves, but instead, you should calculate Gini index gain, which means subtract root Gini index.

author: @GQElvie
text: very well explained.  I am sure it is in another one of your videos, and I was hoping you can tell me which one:  you mentioned about confidence at the end.  so, how to you resolve the STRENGTH of your confidence?  for example, you may put criteria to the number of values in a node (say 10 or more), but one with 7 and 3 in one node (70%) is likely not as confident as one with (say, 68 and 32)... 68%.  in other words, I would think there is some kind of a hypothesis test that declares how confident one is in a nodes statement.  Thanks  John

author: @knowledgedistiller
text: Great video! It cleared a lot of stuff up. I'm using this video as a reference in implementing classification trees (eventually hoping to work my way up to forests) from scratch in python.   One question I have is, the algorithm presented in the video seems to check every possible option per split, and for the continuous case the number of possible things you need to test scale with the amount of datapoints that the tree is being fitted on (though you probabily don't need to test the average between _every_ pair of datapoints when the amount of data is sufficiently large). I have not done a time complexity analysis, but I feel like as the number of features and datapoints increase, the tree will take a LOT more time to fit to the data (even if you define a max depth hyperparameter).  Are there any tricks/techniques you can point me to that would reduce the computation needed to make the tree and/or whether these concerns are even valid?
